shortdesc.ph: Used to configure spatial audio parameters.

plentry.pd:
The azimuth angle of the remote user or media player relative to the local user, in degrees. The range is [0, 360].
0: (Default) Front.
90: Left.
180: Back.
270: Right.
360: Front.

The elevation angle of the remote user or media player relative to the local user, in degrees. The range is [-90, 90].
0: (Default) No rotation on the horizontal plane.
-90: Rotated 90 degrees downward.
90: Rotated 90 degrees upward.
The distance between the remote user or media player and the local user, in meters. The range is [1, 50]. Default is 1 meter.

The orientation angle of the remote user or media player relative to the local user, in degrees. The range is [0, 180].
0: (Default) The sound source faces the listener.
180: The sound source faces away from the listener.

Whether to enable audio blur processing:
: Enable audio blur.
: (Default) Disable audio blur.

Whether to enable air absorption effect to simulate the attenuation of sound during air transmission. High-frequency sounds attenuate faster than low-frequency sounds over distance.
: (Default) Enable air absorption. Make sure speaker_attenuation is not 0, otherwise this setting has no effect.
: Disable air absorption.

The attenuation coefficient of the remote user or media player's sound. The range is [0, 1].
0: Broadcast mode. Volume and timbre do not attenuate with distance. The local user hears the same volume and timbre regardless of distance.
(0, 0.5): Weak attenuation mode. Volume and timbre slightly attenuate during transmission, making the sound propagate farther than in real environments. Requires enable_air_absorb to be enabled.
0.5: (Default) Simulates real-world volume attenuation. Equivalent to not setting speaker_attenuation.
(0.5, 1]: Strong attenuation mode. Volume and timbre attenuate rapidly during transmission. Requires enable_air_absorb to be enabled.

pd.note: This parameter applies to scenarios with fast-moving sound sources (e.g., racing games). It is not recommended for typical audio/video interaction scenarios (e.g., voice chat, co-hosting, or online karaoke). After enabling this parameter, it is recommended to call , , and at fixed intervals (e.g., every 30 ms) to continuously update the relative distance between the sound source and the receiver. The following factors may cause unpredictable Doppler effects or audio jitter: long or irregular update intervals, or distance information loss due to network packet loss or delay.
pd.ph: Whether to enable the Doppler effect: When there is relative movement between the sound source and the receiver, the pitch perceived by the receiver changes.

plentry.pd:
Azimuth of the remote user or media player relative to the local user, in degrees. Range: [0, 360]. Values:
0 (default): Front.
90: Left.
180: Back.
270: Right.
360: Front.

Elevation of the remote user or media player relative to the local user, in degrees. Range: [-90, 90]. Values:
0 (default): No vertical rotation.
-90: Rotated 90 degrees downward.
90: Rotated 90 degrees upward.
Distance between the remote user or media player and the local user, in meters. Range: [1, 50]. Default is 1 meter.

Orientation angle of the remote user or media player relative to the local user, in degrees. Range: [0, 180]. Values:
0 (default): Same orientation as the listener.
180: Facing the listener.

Whether to enable audio blur processing:
: Enable audio blur.
(default): Disable audio blur.

pd.note: speaker_attenuation must not be 0, otherwise this setting will not take effect.
pd.ph: Whether to enable air absorption. When enabled, simulates the attenuation of sound waves during propagation in air. High frequencies attenuate faster than low frequencies.

pd.note: Weak and strong attenuation modes require enable_air_absorb to be enabled.
pd.ph: Sound attenuation coefficient of the remote user or media player. Range: [0, 1].

ul.li: 0: Broadcast mode. Volume and quality do not attenuate with distance.
(0, 0.5): Weak attenuation. Volume and quality attenuate slightly with distance.
0.5 (default): Simulates real-world attenuation. Equivalent to not setting this parameter.
(0.5, 1]: Strong attenuation. Volume and quality attenuate rapidly with distance.

This parameter is suitable for scenarios with high-speed moving sound sources (e.g., racing games). Not recommended for general audio/video interaction scenarios (e.g., voice chat, co-hosting, online karaoke).
After enabling, Agora recommends you periodically (e.g., every 30 ms) call , , or to continuously update the relative distance between sound source and receiver.
If the update interval is too long, irregular, or distance info is lost due to network packet loss or delay, Doppler effect may behave abnormally or cause audio jitter.

pd.ph: Whether to enable Doppler effect. When there is relative motion between the sound source and the receiver, the pitch heard by the receiver changes.
